TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit ModelVisual3D extends System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Visual3D implements class System.Windows.Markup.IAddChild

remarks.format:
## Remarks Provides services and properties that are common to all visual objects, including hit-testing, coordinate transformation, and bounding-box calculations.
The <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.ModelVisual3D> class has a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.ModelVisual3D.Children%2A> property that enables you to build a tree structure of <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.ModelVisual3D> objects.
<xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.ModelVisual3D> objects are optimized as scene nodes. For example, they cache bounds. Whenever you can, use <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.ModelVisual3D> objects for unique instances of objects within your scene. This usage contrasts with that of <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Model3D> objects, which are lightweight objects that are optimized to be shared and reused. For example, use a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Model3D> object to build a model of a car; and use ten <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.ModelVisual3D> objects to place ten cars in your scene.
## Examples The following example shows an instance of ModelVisual3D in markup. `myTeapot` refers to a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.MeshGeometry3D> defined externally. You can substitute any geometry of your own.
[!code-xaml[animate3drotation#Animate3DRotation3DN3](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/Animate3DRotation/CS/Window1.xaml#animate3drotation3dn3)]
